awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Fire Influences on Forest Recovery and Associated Ecosystem Feedbacks in Arctic Larch Forests.

por.por_cntn:
Background

Boreal forests play an important role in Earth's climate and terrestrial systems, comprising ∼50% of global terrestrial carbon stocks while occupying only 20% of Earth’s vegetated land area. Fire is the most important natural disturbance in this biome. The anticipated intensification of boreal fire regimes due to climate change could potentially decrease ecosystem C storage (which would amplify climate change) and increase the reflectivity (albedo) of the land surface (which would moderate climate change). Eurasian larch (Larix) forests occupy 20% of the boreal forest biome, but relatively little is known about the impacts of wildfire in this ecosystem. We studied fire regimes and the impacts of wildfire on larch forests in northeast Siberia using field surveys and satellite data.

 

Key research findings

Over recent decades, dry years led to increases in the number and size of fires in larch forests of northeast Siberia. Larger fires tended to occur in flat, low-elevation areas with high levels of soil carbon. The effect of future climate change on fire regimes in this region is uncertain: the expected mean increase in precipitation could lead to reduced burn area, but greater interannual variability in precipitation could lead to unprecedented extremes in fire size, especially in lowland areas with large stores of soil carbon.

In addition to the frequency and size of fires, another key uncertainty is understanding how fires in Siberian larch forests affect ecosystem carbon storage. In the relatively well-studied boreal forests of North American, wildfires typically kill the majority of trees within the burn perimeter. In contrast, the prevailing view is that fires in Eurasian larch forests tend to be low-intensity ground fires. Contrary to this paradigm, our field data suggest that fires in larch forests in northeast Siberia kill about 80% of trees. Comparing our field data to previous studies of North American boreal forest fires suggest that fire-induced aboveground carbon loss (combustion of live vegetation and litter) in Siberian larch forests is greater than in North America, but soil carbon loss is lower. These differences highlight the importance of studying fire regimes and their impacts across different boreal regions.

 

Education and outreach

We organized a training session to help middle school teachers incorporate Arctic science into their lesson plans. We produced a documentary film, “Smoldering Ice: A Siberian Arctic Research Expedition,” to educate the general public about the scientific themes and logistical challenges of our project. The film was showcased in the 2021 Colorado Environmental Film Festival, won “Best Documentary” at the Los Angeles 2020 Student Film festival, and won the “Silver Award for Best Independent Films of 2020” by Spotlight Documentary Films.
